name: Take this I Write The Songs Quiz! Difficult Trivia |  Music Mixture

questions.text: Who wrote the song with the following words: "Amazing grace how sweet the sound that saved a wretch like me"?
questions.explanation:
John Newton.

	"Amazing Grace" was first published in 1779. Newton was a slave trader for many years until he started studying Christian theology and became a clergyman. (wikipedia.com)

questions.text:
Who wrote the song that goes like this: 
"Jenny, Jenny, who can I turn to?
You give me something I can hold onto
I know you think I'm like the others before
Who saw your name and number on the wall"?
questions.explanation:
Alex Call and Jim Keller.

	This song was made popular by Tommy Tutone. According to the writer there was no actual Jenny, both the name and number were made up. However, it did cause a surge of people all over dialing that number to ask for Jenny. (wikipedia.com)

questions.text:
Who wrote the song with the following lyrics: 
"'Cause that's my funday 
My I don't have to runday"?
questions.explanation:
Prince.

	Prince wrote this song under the name of Christopher. It was originally written for the group Apollonia6 but given to The Bangels two years later. (wikipedia.com)

questions.text: Who wrote "the songs that make the whole world sing"?
questions.explanation:
Bruce Johnston.

	This song was made popular by Barry Manilow. It won a Grammy Award for Song of the Year in 1977.

questions.text:
Who wrote the song with these lyrics: 
"And now it's all right, it's OK
And you may look the other way
We can try to understand
The New York Times' effect on man"?
questions.explanation:
Barry, Robin and Maurice Gibb.

	Performed by the Bee Gees this song was featured in the soundtrack of "Saturday Night Fever" staring John Travolta. It was released in 1977.

questions.text:
Who wrote this song: 
"She's like the wind through my tree 
She rides the night next to me 
She leads me through moonlight 
Only to burn me with the sun 
She's taken my heart 
But she doesn't know what she's done"?
questions.explanation:
Patrick Swayze and Stacy Widelitz.

	"She's Like the Wind" was written for the movie "Dirty Dancing" staring Patrick Swayze and Jennifer Grey. Patrick Swayze not only wrote it but also sings the song which also features Wendy Fraser. (wikipedia.com)

questions.text: Who wrote the popular Christmas tune that goes like this: "Dashing through the snow in a one-horse open sleigh"?
questions.explanation:
James Lord Pierpont.

	"Jingle Bells" was originally written as a Thanksgiving song but has become one of the most popular Christmas tunes song today. It was originally titled "One Horse Open Sleigh". (wikipedia.com)

questions.text: Who wrote the song that states, "We are family, I got all my sisters with me"?
questions.explanation:
Bernard Edwards and Niles Rodgers.

	This song was rejected by Atlantic Records at first but was picked up as a single album that eventually went Gold. It was released in 1979.

questions.text:
Who wrote the song that goes like this: 
"Hark, now hear the angels sing
A newborn King today
And man will live forevermore
Because of Christmas day"
questions.explanation:
Jester Hairston.

	Jester Hairston was born in 1901 and died in 2000. "Mary's Boy Child" was first recorded by Harry Belafonte in 1956.

questions.text: Who wrote this song, performed by Olivia Newton-John in "Grease": "Guess mine is not the first heart broken"?
questions.explanation:
John Farrar.

	"Hopelessly Devoted To You" was originally performed by Elizabeth Andrews, however, the most popular version is the one song by Olivia Newton-John in "Grease". It recieved a Grammy nomination but lost to "Last Dance".
